clinical_study.brief_title: Dietary Intervention to Mitigate Adverse Consequences of Night Work
clinical_study.official_title: Food Timing to Mitigate Adverse Consequences of Night Work

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: Shift work increases the risk for diabetes possibly due to the adverse metabolic effects of circadian misalignment. As shift work is not foreseen to disappear, the development of individually-targeted therapies for metabolic health in these vulnerable shift workers is urgently needed. This research will determine whether our dietary intervention can mitigate the adverse metabolic effects of circadian misalignment, which may help in the design of evidence-based dietary interventions to improve the metabolic health in shift workers.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline glucose tolerance on test day
primary_outcome.description: Change in incremental glucose area under the curve

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in microbial community structure assessed by shotgun sequence data from oral and gut microbiome
primary_outcome.description: Shotgun metagenomics sequencing in saliva, stool, and rectal swab samples for in-depth interrogation of the microbial community structure (species taxonomic level) and function

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Insulin sensitivity Index by the Oral Minimal Model on test day
secondary_outcome.description: Derived by the Oral Minimal Model based on glucose and insulin profile after a mixed meal test

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline levels of serum markers of gut microbiota, intestinal barrier integrity and inflammatory state on test day
secondary_outcome.description: Serum markers of gut microbiota (SCFA), intestinal barrier integrity (zonulin, LPS and LBP, and inflammatory state (cytokines)

arm_group.description: Control condition first, then to Dietary intervention
Dietary intervention first, then to Control condition.

intervention.description: manipulate feeding-fasting cycle to be aligned or misaligned with the circadian system

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants will be younger (18-45 y), healthy, non-diabetic with BMI 20-30, European/Hispanic/African-American ancestry, and without medication use (excepting oral contraceptives). Participants must be free from acute, chronic, or debilitating medical conditions.
Exclusion Criteria:
- We will exclude people with reported or actigraphically measured habitual outpatient sleep durations of <5h or >9h and people who have recently (within last 6 months) taken antibiotics.
- major visual or auditory handicaps
